questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the immunology of psoriasis is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease with a strong genetic predisposition and autoimmune pathogenic traits.

The immunopathogenesis of psoriasis primarily involves the TNF-α–IL-23–Th17 axis, not Th2 dominance (Option A ruled out)

  • Epidermal dendritic cells recognise injury and secrete AMPs, which are overexpressed in psoriatic skin.
  • They activate Th1 and Th17 pathways by producing TNF-α, IL-23, and IL-12.
  • Th17 cells secrete IL-17, IL-21, and IL-22, leading to keratinocyte proliferation and plaque formation.
  • These cytokines are key therapeutic targets in psoriasis management.
  • The specific cytokine inhibitors have proven the importance of these inflammatory cytokines, which show strong anti-inflammatory action against psoriatic skin inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

Antimicrobial peptides (Option B): Antimicrobial peptides (like LL-37) are over expressed in psoriasis, not reduced.

Th17 helper cells reduced:(Option D): Th17 cells are increased and are crucial mediators of psoriatic inflammation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The TNF-α mediates psoriasis–IL-23–Th17 axis.
  • Antimicrobial peptides are overexpressed.
  • Biologics target TNF-α and IL-17 for treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psoriasis typically affects the skin, but may also affect osteoporosis, coronary artery disease, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and has been associated with several diseases.

  • Inflammation is not limited to the psoriatic skin and has been shown to affect different organ systems.
  • Thus, it has been postulated that psoriasis is a systemic inflammatory disease rather than a solely dermatological disease.

Associated systemic diseases include:

  • Hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and coronary artery disease (Option B) - highlighting the cardiovascular risk.
  • Cerebrocardiovascular disease and metabolic syndrome - linking to metabolic inflammation.
  • Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (Option C) – reflecting systemic metabolic disturbances.
  • Osteoporosis (Option A) – indicating skeletal involvement, possibly linked to chronic systemic inflammation.
  • Type 2 diabetes and depression – emphasising the broader systemic and psychological impacts.

Key Takeaways:

  • Psoriasis is a systemic inflammatory disease with multi-organ involvement.
  • Associations include cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, NAFLD, osteoporosis, diabetes, and depression.
  • A multidisciplinary approach to management is important

questions.text: Which type of psoriasis is most commonly associated with a preceding history of streptococcal pharyngitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guttate psoriasis is classically preceded by streptococcal pharyngitis, especially in children and young adults.

  • Guttate psoriasis presents with multiple small, drop-like erythematous lesions with fine scale.
  • Lesions commonly appear 1–3 weeks after an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • It commonly involves the trunk and proximal limbs, particularly in children and adolescents.
  • It often resolves spontaneously or responds well to phototherapy or topical therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Flexural psoriasis (Option A): Involves skin folds like axillae and groin; not triggered by streptococcal infection.

Pustular psoriasis (Option C): Presents with sterile pustules; typically not related to streptococcal infections.

Erythrodermic psoriasis (Option D): Involves widespread erythema and scaling; often drug-triggered or due to withdrawal of steroids/systemic agents.

Key Takeaways:

  • Guttate psoriasis is the variant most strongly linked to preceding streptococcal infections.
  • It presents with numerous small, drop-like, scaly papules.
  • Prompt treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis can prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with the sudden onset of multiple, small, drop-like red papules with fine scales distributed symmetrically over his trunk and proximal limbs. He had a sore throat two weeks ago. What is the most likely variant of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guttate psoriasis presents with multiple, small, drop-like erythematous papules (2–6 mm) with fine scaling, often triggered by recent streptococcal pharyngitis.

  • Commonly affects children and young adults.
  • Preceding Group A Streptococcal infection (usually pharyngitis) is seen in ~80% of cases.
  • Lesions are sudden in onset, symmetrically distributed over the trunk and proximal limbs.
  • The papules are round, erythematous, with delicate, silvery white scale.
  • Pathophysiology involves immune activation via molecular mimicry, with T-cell–mediated response against keratinocytes.
  • Management includes:
    • Topical corticosteroids
    • Vitamin D analogues
    • Narrowband UVB phototherapy
    • Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) if streptococcal infection is confirmed. 

Explanation of other options:

Erythrodermic psoriasis (Option B): Widespread erythema and scaling (>90% BSA); not drop-like lesions.

Pustular psoriasis (Option C): Sterile pustules on erythematous base; more severe, not papular or guttate.

Inverse psoriasis (Option D): Smooth, shiny plaques in body folds; lacks typical scale or trunk involvement.

Key Takeaway:

Guttate psoriasis presents with scattered drop-like scaly papules, often 1–3 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis, and responds well to topical therapy or phototherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not cause exacerbation of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penicillin is not implicated in the exacerbation or triggering of psoriasis, unlike several other systemic drugs.

  • Drug-induced psoriasis or exacerbation can be precipitated or worsened by several pharmacologic agents in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • Confirmed drug triggers include:
    • Beta blockers(Option A)
    • Lithium(Option D)
    • Antimalarials (chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine)
    • NSAIDs
    • ACE inhibitors(Option B)
    • Interferons
  • These agents may induce psoriasis via immune dysregulation, altered T-cell signalling, or keratinocyte proliferation.
  • Penicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, has no known association with psoriasis flare-ups or induction. It remains safe for use in psoriatic patients unless allergic or contraindicated for other reasons.

Key Takeaway:
While many drugs can trigger or worsen psoriasis, penicillin is not one of them and is generally considered safe in psoriatic patients.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of multiple red, scaly plaques over his elbows, knees, and lower back. The lesions are well-demarcated, symmetrical, and have a silvery white scale. He reports that new lesions tend to appear at sites of minor cuts or scratches. His father has similar skin issues. Which of the following clinical signs best explains this?
questions.solution:
Appearance of psoriatic lesions at sites of trauma is known as the Koebner phenomenon, a hallmark feature of psoriasis.

  • The Koebner phenomenon (isomorphic response) refers to the development of typical lesions of a skin disease at sites of trauma, such as cuts, pressure, or friction.
  • Seen in psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.
  • It indicates active disease and may be precipitated by injury, tattooing, or scratching.
  • This patient has chronic plaque psoriasis, suggested by well-demarcated, scaly plaques over extensor surfaces and a family history.
  • The positive Koebner phenomenon helps differentiate psoriasis from other dermatoses.

Explanation of other options:

Nikolsky sign (Option A): Seen in pemphigus vulgaris; gentle rubbing causes epidermal separation.

Darier's sign (Option B): Urtication seen in mastocytosis upon stroking the lesion.

Auspitz sign (Option D): Pinpoint bleeding on removal of scales; also seen in psoriasis but not related to trauma-induced lesions.

Key Takeaway:

Koebner phenomenon is the development of psoriatic lesions at sites of trauma, indicative of active disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic red, scaly plaques symmetrically distributed on his elbows and knees. The plaques are sharply demarcated from the surrounding skin and exhibit a pale peripheral zone encircling them. The patient reports that the plaques appeared to have cleared from the centre at times and are associated with mild itching. What is the most likely clinical sign observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Woronoff ring is a transient pale halo surrounding psoriatic plaques, especially during resolution or treatment response.

  • Seen in: Chronic plaque psoriasis, especially during lesion involution or after topical steroid or phototherapy.
  • Appearance: A translucent hypopigmented ring around an erythematous, scaly psoriatic plaque.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Prostaglandin synthesis inhibition (by topical corticosteroids or UV therapy) leads to vasoconstriction, producing the pale halo.
    • Indicates a healing phase or partial lesion regression.
  • Clinical importance: Helps differentiate resolving psoriasis from other annular dermatoses.
  • Common locations: Elbows, knees, trunk-extensor surfaces.

Explanation of other options:

Auspitz sign (Option A): Pinpoint bleeding on removal of scales—seen in active psoriasis, not linked to pale halo.

Koebner’s phenomenon (Option B): New lesions appear at trauma sites, not related to lesion clearing.

Wickham’s striae (Option D): White, reticulate lines seen in lichen planus, not psoriasis.

Key Takeaway:

Woronoff ring is a pale zone seen during resolution of psoriatic plaques, often after treatment-induced prostaglandin inhibition.

questions.text: All are true about Psoriasis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psoriasis does not involve mucosal membranes, which helps distinguish it from other papulosquamous disorders.

  • Psoriasis is a chronic immune-mediated inflammatory disorder primarily involving the skin, nails, and joints.
  • Typical skin lesions are well-demarcated plaques with silvery white scales.
  • Nail involvement occurs in ~30–50% of patients and includes pitting, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis.
  • Psoriatic arthritis affects ~20–30% of patients and may be severe.
  • Mucosal involvement is absent, which helps distinguish psoriasis from conditions like lichen planus or pemphigus vulgaris.

Clinical Features of Psoriasis: 

Explanation of other options:

Silvery white scaling (Option A): Characteristic scale seen in plaque psoriasis.

Nail pitting (Option B): Common nail finding due to parakeratosis of nail matrix.

Arthritis (Option D): Psoriatic arthritis may precede or follow skin involvement.

Key Takeaway:
Psoriasis affects the skin, nails, and joints, but never involves mucosal surfaces, helping in clinical differentiation.

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis was started on systemic steroids. After stopping the treatment, the patient developed universally red scaly skin with plaques losing their margins all over his body. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Erythrodermic psoriasis is a severe, potentially life-threatening variant of psoriasis characterised by generalised erythema and scaling involving >90% of the body surface area.

  • Definition: Erythrodermic psoriasis is a generalised inflammatory response where pre-existing psoriatic plaques lose their margin and merge into widespread redness and scaling.
  • Pathophysiology: Represents a dysregulated immune response with widespread activation of Th1/Th17 cytokines and impaired skin barrier function.
  • Precipitating factors:
    • Sudden withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids (most common)
    • Overuse or irritation from topical agents
    • Infections or stress
  • Clinical features:
    • Diffuse erythema and fine scaling of the entire skin
    • Loss of sharply demarcated plaques
    • Severe pruritus, malaise, and constitutional symptoms
  • Complications:
    • Thermoregulatory dysfunction → hypothermia or hyperthermia
    • Fluid and electrolyte imbalance
    • Hypoproteinemia due to increased transepidermal loss
    • Secondary infections (e.g., sepsis)

In this patient, the history of corticosteroid use followed by widespread erythema and scaling strongly supports erythrodermic psoriasis over other options.

Explanation of other options:

Drug-induced reaction (Option A): While steroids are a trigger, this is not a nonspecific drug reaction—it specifically causes erythrodermic psoriasis.

Pustular psoriasis (Option B): Characterised by sterile pustules over an erythematous base—not uniform scaling and redness.

Bacterial infection (Option C): Can exacerbate psoriasis but would present with localised signs or systemic sepsis, not generalised erythroderma.

Key Takeaway:
Withdrawal of systemic steroids in psoriasis can precipitate erythrodermic psoriasis, presenting as generalised erythema and scaling with systemic complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following nail changes is commonly seen in psoriasis?
1. Pitting
2. Pterygium formation
3. Subungual hyperkeratosis
4. Thinning of nails
5. Oil spots
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pitting, subungual hyperkeratosis, and oil spots (salmon patches) are classical nail findings in psoriasis.

  • Nail psoriasis affects the nail matrix, nail bed, and hyponychium.
  • Matrix involvement →
    • Pitting – shallow, uniform depressions (most frequent finding)
    • Leukonychia, longitudinal ridges
  • Nail bed involvement →
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis
    • Onycholysis
    • Oil drop sign/salmon patch – translucent yellow-red spot under nail plate (most specific finding)
  • Pterygium formation is a hallmark of lichen planus, not psoriasis.
  • Thinning (onychoschizia) is due to ageing or nutrient deficiency, not psoriatic changes.

Pterygium formation (Option 2): Seen in lichen planus due to scarring of the proximal nail fold.

Thinning of nails (Option 4): Caused by trauma, iron deficiency, or ageing—not psoriasis.

Key Takeaway:
Psoriatic nail findings include pitting, subungual hyperkeratosis, and the oil drop sign, highly diagnostic of nail involvement in psoriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in histopathology of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microabscesses in psoriasis are seen within the stratum corneum (Munro's abscess) and upper stratum spinosum (Kogoj pustules)—not at papillary tips.

Histopathological Features of Psoriasis :

Stratum Corneum:

  • Parakeratosis(Option A) – Retention of nuclei in stratum corneum due to rapid turnover
  • Munro’s microabscess – Aggregates of neutrophils within the stratum corneum

Stratum Granulosum:

  • Hypogranulosis – Thinning or complete absence of the granular cell layer

Stratum Spinosum:

  • Acanthosis – Epidermal hyperplasia
  • Spongiform pustule of Kogoj – Neutrophil collections in upper spinous layer

Stratum Basale + Dermal Papillae:

  • Rete ridges elongation(Option B) → described as "Camel foot appearance"
  • Suprapapillary thinning (Option C)– Thinned epidermis above dermal papillae
  • Dilated capillaries in dermal papillae – May cause the Auspitz sign
  • Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate in the upper dermis

Key Takeaway:
Papillary tip microabscess is not a histological feature of psoriasis; key changes involve parakeratosis, neutrophil accumulation in stratum corneum, and rete ridge elongation.

questions.text: Spongiform neutrophilic collections in stratum spinosum are seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of spongiform neutrophilic pustules in the stratum spinosum strongly supports the diagnosis of psoriasis vulgaris.

  • Spongiform pustule of Kogoj:
    • Represents clusters of neutrophils within the upper stratum spinosum, arranged in a sponge-like fashion.
  • Microabscess of Munro:
    • Neutrophilic collections in the stratum corneum.
  • Other features:
    • Parakeratosis (retained nuclei in stratum corneum)
    • Hypogranulosis (reduction in granular layer)
    • Regular elongation of rete ridges (camel foot appearance)
    • Suprapapillary thinning
    • Dilated dermal capillaries

Explanation of Other Options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at dermoepidermal junction; saw-tooth rete ridges—no neutrophilic pustules.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B): Shows suprabasal acantholysis with "row of tombstones"; no neutrophilic spongiform pustules.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C): Features Pautrier's microabscesses are composed of atypical lymphocytes, not neutrophils.

Key Takeaway:
Spongiform pustules of Kogoj are a classic microscopic finding in psoriasis vulgaris, indicating neutrophilic infiltration in the stratum spinosum.

questions.text: Isomorphic phenomenon is not typically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Koebner phenomenon refers to the development of new lesions of a pre-existing dermatosis at sites of trauma; it is not seen in pityriasis rosea.

  • Seen in: Psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo.
  • Not seen in: Pityriasis rosea, which typically follows a viral trigger and does not respond to trauma with lesion development.
  • Mechanism:
    • Skin trauma activates innate immune cells like plasmacytoid dendritic cells, producing LL-37, antimicrobial peptides, and immune complexes.
    • These trigger Th1/Th17/Th22-mediated inflammation, leading to keratinocyte hyperproliferation and new plaque formation.
  • More frequent in individuals with HLA-C*06:02 (psoriasis genetic predisposition).

Key Takeaway:
Pityriasis rosea does not show the Koebner phenomenon—a feature seen in psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis used an ayurvedic paste from a local quack. One week later, he presented to the OPD with involvement>90% of body surface area, the clinical image as shown below. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methotrexate is the treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis due to its systemic immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory effects.

  • A severe, potentially life-threatening form of psoriasis involving >90% of the body surface area.
  • Common triggers include:
    • Sudden withdrawal of corticosteroids
    • Irritant topical agents (e.g., coal tar or herbal pastes)
  • Symptoms:
    • Diffuse erythema and scaling
    • Loss of hair and nails
    • Systemic symptoms – fever, malaise, dehydration
    • Complications: fluid/electrolyte imbalance, hypoproteinemia, secondary infections

Treatment Rationale:

  • Methotrexate (7.5–25 mg/week):
    • Modulates T-cell proliferation and suppresses keratinocyte hyperplasia
    • Inhibits pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-17, IL-22, TNF-α)
    • Especially effective in HLA-C*06:02 positive patients
  • Other systemic agents: Cyclosporine or acitretin (if methotrexate contraindicated)
  • Supportive care: Fluids, electrolytes, temperature control

Explanation of Other Options:

Corticosteroids (Option A): Systemic steroids can worsen psoriasis on withdrawal; contraindicated in EP.

Coal tar (Option C): Topical agent, irritant in erythrodermic skin; not suitable for generalised disease.

Topical corticosteroids (Option D): Insufficient for systemic involvement; used only adjunctively in limited disease.

Key Takeaway:
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for erythrodermic psoriasis, which presents with widespread erythema, scaling, and systemic features.

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis was started on treatment by a local practitioner. He suddenly stopped the treatment on his own, and the patient developed lesions over the body as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Generalised pustular psoriasis (GPP) is a rare, severe, and potentially life-threatening variant of psoriasis characterised by widespread sterile pustules on an erythematous base, often accompanied by systemic symptoms. Also known as von Zumbusch type.

Pathophysiology:

  • Triggered by:
    • Sudden withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids
    • Infections, pregnancy, hypocalcemia, or irritant topical agents
  • Cytokine cascade: Overexpression of IL-36, IL-1β, IL-17 → leads to massive neutrophilic infiltration
  • Histology:
    • Spongiform pustules of Kogoj in stratum spinosum
    • Parakeratosis, acanthosis, and elongation of rete ridges

Clinical Features:

  • Cutaneous:
    • Sudden eruption of "lakes of pus"—coalescing sterile pustules on erythematous plaques
    • Flexural predominance, but may become generalised
  • Systemic symptoms:
    • High-grade fever, malaise, chills, arthralgia
    • May develop hypocalcemia, electrolyte imbalance, and secondary infections
  • In children:
    • Associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, Osteitis)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

AGEP (Option B): Sudden drug reaction with pustules, but histology shows eosinophils and no history of psoriasis

Bullous impetigo (Option C): Caused by Staph aureus; pustules rupture to form honey-colored crusts—infectious, not sterile

Leukocytoclastic vasculitis (Option D): Palpable purpura, not pustules; histology shows neutrophilic infiltration of vessel walls

Key Takeaway:

Generalised pustular psoriasis (von Zumbusch disease) presents with coalescing sterile pustules ("lakes of pus") on an erythematous background, often after sudden withdrawal of systemic therapy.

questions.text: A 7-month pregnant woman presents with fever, widespread erythema, and pustules forming "lakes of pus", starting from intertriginous areas and now spreading. What is the drug of choice for urgent control of complications in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Systemic corticosteroids are the drug of choice for urgent control in impetigo herpetiformis (generalised pustular psoriasis of pregnancy).

Impetigo Herpetiformis (GPP of Pregnancy)

  • Rare, life-threatening pustular dermatosis occurring in late pregnancy
  • Clinically presents with:
    • Fever, erythema, and sterile pustules coalescing into "lakes of pus"
    • Begins in intertriginous areas → spreads centrifugally
    • Associated systemic features: fever, malaise, hypocalcemia
    • Worsens rapidly without treatment

Fetal Complications:

  • Preterm labor
  • Stillbirth
  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Neonatal death in severe, untreated cases

Management Overview: 

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Retinoids (Option B): Highly teratogenic; absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

Methotrexate (Option C): Causes fetal death and congenital malformations.

PUVA (Option D): Not safe during pregnancy; ineffective in acute settings.

Key Takeaway:
In impetigo herpetiformis, systemic corticosteroids are the first-line drug for rapid control, while ciclosporin is preferred for longer-term management in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50 year old man presented with skin lesions as seen in the image below. On examination, painful swollen fingers were noted along with an the inflamed wrist joint. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. In most patients, psoriasis develops first, but in some, joint disease may precede or coincide with skin disease.

Characteristic features include:

  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement (as seen in the images).
  • Dactylitis (sausage digits) due to flexor tenosynovitis.
  • : Inflammation at the  tendon/ligament insertion sites. Common sites: Achilles tendon, plantar fascia, patellar tendon.
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common pattern.
  • Other patterns include symmetric polyarthritis, arthritis mutilans, and spondyloarthropathy.
  • Nail changes (pitting, onycholysis, subungual hyperkeratosis) are often seen and are an important clue.
  • The prevalence of psoriatic arthritis is higher in patients with severe psoriasis, nail involvement, and scalp psoriasis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Reactive arthritis (Option A): Post-infectious; predominantly affects large joints of lower limbs with urethritis/conjunctivitis

Osteoarthritis (Option C): Non-inflammatory; involves weight-bearing joints, sparing DIP with no systemic signs

Pseudogout (Option D): Acute monoarthritis (usually knee); shows chondrocalcinosis due to CPPD crystals

Key Takeaway:

Psoriatic arthritis presents with DIP joint arthritis, dactylitis, nail changes, and may be classified using CASPAR or Moll & Wright criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following radiographic features is most characteristic of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pencil-in-cup deformity is the hallmark radiographic finding in psoriatic arthritis, resulting from erosive changes in the phalanges.

Pencil-in-cup deformity:

  • The distal phalanx tapers into a pencil shape due to marginal erosions, while the adjacent proximal phalanx forms a concave cup
  • Most commonly seen in DIP joints

Key Takeaway:
Pencil-in-cup deformity on X-ray is a distinctive and diagnostic radiologic sign of psoriatic arthritis, especially involving the DIP joints.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common clinical pattern of psoriatic arthritis, often involving large and small joints in an asymmetric distribution.

  • A seronegative inflammatory arthritis is seen in patients with psoriasis
  • Joint disease may precede, coincide with, or follow the appearance of skin lesions
  • Nail changes (pitting, onycholysis) and DIP involvement are strong clues

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Spondylitis (Option A): Affects axial skeleton; less common than peripheral arthritis

Arthritis mutilans (Option C): Rare, deforming variant with severe osteolysis and joint destruction

Symmetrical polyarthritis (Option D): Mimics rheumatoid arthritis, but not the predominant pattern in PsA

Key Takeaway:
Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common pattern of psoriatic arthritis and helps differentiate it from rheumatoid arthritis and axial spondyloarthropathies.

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions as shown below. They are present only on knees. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales over the knees in an otherwise systemically stable patient indicate localised psoriasis vulgaris, best treated with topical corticosteroids.

Diagnosis: Psoriasis Vulgaris (Localised)

  • The most common variant of psoriasis
  • Classic sites: extensor surfaces (elbows, knees), scalp, lumbosacral region
  • Presents as red plaques with adherent silvery-white scale
  • Severity is based on Body Surface Area (BSA), Psoriasis Area Severity Index (PASI), and Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI)

Management of Psoriasis Vulgaris Based on BSA:

Topical Steroids Are Preferred Here:

  • Lesions are localised to the knees
  • BSA involvement is <10%
  • High-potency topical corticosteroids provide effective inflammation control
  • Often combined with salicylic acid to aid scale removal

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

NBUVB (Option A): Used for moderate to severe psoriasis, not localized lesions

Methotrexate (Option B): Systemic drug used when BSA >10%, erythroderma, or psoriatic arthritis

Acitretin (Option D): Reserved for pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis; contraindicated in women of childbearing age

Key Takeaway:
Topical corticosteroids are first-line therapy for mild plaque psoriasis involving <10% BSA.

questions.text: What is the only definitive indication for systemic corticosteroids in the management of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Systemic corticosteroids are reserved for pregnancy-associated generalised pustular psoriasis (impetigo herpetiformis), where rapid control is critical to protect maternal and fetal outcomes.

Impetigo Herpetiformis (GPP of Pregnancy)

  • A rare, life-threatening pustular dermatosis occurring in late pregnancy
  • Clinically presents with:
    • Erythema and sterile pustules coalescing into lakes of pus
    • Predilection for intertriginous areas
    • Systemic features: fever, leukocytosis, elevated ESR/CRP, hypoalbuminemia

Management Overview

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Guttate psoriasis (Option A): Managed with topical therapy or phototherapy, not systemic steroids

Chronic plaque psoriasis (Option C): Treated with topicals, methotrexate, or biologics; steroids may cause severe rebound flares

Erythroderma (Option D): Systemic steroids are not first-line due to rebound risk; safer systemic immunosuppressants are preferred

Key Takeaway:
Systemic corticosteroids are not routinely used in psoriasis, but are justified in pregnancy-associated GPP (impetigo herpetiformis) for urgent control of inflammation to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is a newer topical retinoid recently introduced for the treatment of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tazarotene is the only topical retinoid approved and recently introduced for use in psoriasis vulgaris.

  • It is a third-generation topical retinoid, available in 0.05–0.1% gel or cream formulations.
  • Acts by normalising keratinocyte differentiation, reducing epidermal hyperproliferation and inflammation.
  • Useful in reducing scaling, erythema, and thickness of psoriatic plaques.
  • Often used in combination with topical corticosteroids to improve efficacy and reduce irritation.
  • Known for its keratolytic and keratoplastic properties.
  • It is Category X in pregnancy—contraindicated due to teratogenic risk.
  • Local side effects include burning, redness, irritation, and photosensitivity.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Adapalene (Option A): Indicated for acne vulgaris, not psoriasis.

Alitretinoin (Option C): Used in chronic hand eczema and Kaposi sarcoma, not approved for psoriasis.

Bexarotene (Option D): Used for cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, not indicated for psoriasis

questions.text: A 35 y/o patient was prescribed 50 mg daily acitretin for chronic plaque psoriasis. Which of the following parameters requires monitoring during therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acitretin therapy requires regular monitoring of liver function, lipid profile, and blood glucose due to its systemic effects and potential toxicity.

Mechanism and Use

  • Acitretin is a second-generation oral retinoid, structurally related to vitamin A.
  • It is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic plaque psoriasis and acts by modulating keratinocyte differentiation and proliferation.
  • Commonly used at a dose of 25–50 mg/day, with effects seen after 4–6 weeks.

Monitoring Requirements

  • Liver function tests (LFTs): Risk of hepatotoxicity with elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT).
  • Lipid profile: Frequently causes hypertriglyceridemia and hypercholesterolemia.
  • Blood sugar: Can cause hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, especially in diabetic patients.
  • Others: May elevate creatine phosphokinase (CPK) and cause reticulocytosis.

Contraindications and Cautions

  • Absolute contraindication in pregnancy (Category X) due to severe teratogenicity.
  • Avoid in patients with severe liver disease.
  • Pregnancy prevention is required for 3 years after stopping therapy due to the long elimination half-life.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Lipid profile (Option A): Needs monitoring due to risk of hyperlipidemia, but not the only parameter.

Liver function (Option B): Important due to hepatotoxicity risk, but others must also be checked.

Blood sugar (Option C): Abnormalities are possible, but alone insufficient.

questions.text: The Ingram regimen is used in the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ingram regimen is a specialised photochemotherapy protocol used for the management of extensive or recalcitrant psoriasis.

  • It combines topical dithranol (anthralin) in Lassar’s paste, tar baths, and UVB phototherapy.
  • This multimodal approach helps suppress keratinocyte hyperproliferation, reduce inflammation, and promote remission.
  • Often employed in day-care or inpatient settings under medical supervision.
  • Compared to other regimens like the Goeckerman regimen (coal tar + UVB), the Ingram regimen substitutes coal tar with dithranol for a more aggressive response.
  • Suitable for moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis, especially when topical treatments alone are ineffective.

Explanation of Other Options

Vitiligo (Option A): Treated with NB-UVB, topical steroids, or calcineurin inhibitors—not dithranol or the Ingram regimen.

Lichen planus (Option C): Managed with topical/systemic steroids and phototherapy, but not using the Ingram regimen.

Lichen nitidus (Option D): Self-limiting and generally does not require aggressive therapy like Ingram's regimen.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of Psoralen in PUVA therapy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Psoralens bind to DNA and, when activated by UVA, cause DNA cross-linking and apoptosis of hyperproliferative keratinocytes in psoriasis.

  • PUVA (Psoralen + UVA) therapy uses long-wave ultraviolet light (320–400 nm) after administering psoralens either orally or topically.
  • Psoralen intercalates between DNA bases, and upon UVA exposure, forms covalent bonds with pyrimidine bases (preferentially thymine), causing permanent DNA cross-links.
  • This leads to apoptosis of keratinocytes and T cells, suppression of immune-mediated inflammation, and reduction in angiogenesis.
  • The therapy reduces hyperproliferation, enhances differentiation, and promotes long-term remission in plaque psoriasis.
  • Commonly used psoralens include 8-MOP, 5-MOP, and T-MOP.
  • PUVA is highly effective for extensive or recalcitrant psoriasis, with clearance rates >90% reported.

Explanation of other options:

Inhibiting protein synthesis (Option B): Not the primary mechanism; PUVA primarily acts via DNA damage.

Inhibiting angiogenesis (Option C): Although angiogenesis is secondarily reduced, it is not the main mechanism.

Inhibiting keratinisation (Option D): PUVA improves keratinocyte differentiation but not via direct inhibition of keratinisation.

Key Takeaway:
PUVA therapy acts via psoralen-induced DNA cross-linking, making it a highly effective and targeted treatment for psoriasis.
